summary: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York today announced criminal charges against a Mexican fingerprint technician who was arrested and charged with illegally reentering the United States after having been removed from the country.  The SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in Tecate, California, alleges that, in September 2016, Mexican national Mario Ruvalcaba-Garcia was arrested by Border Patrol agents and charged in connection with his illegal reentry.  According to the complaint, the government presented to the court documents that purported to show that Beers was a member of IAI or SWGFAST and that, although he followed the ACE-V method of fingerprint analysis, he did not have another fingerprint analyst independently verify his conclusions.  In addition, the complaint alleges that the government misrepresented to the jury that the fingerprint on the 2015 Verification of Removal form was the same one that had been removed in 2015.  Without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, Beers consented to the entry of a final judgment that permanently enjoins him from violating the antifraud provisions of Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder, and orders him to pay disgorgement of ill-gotten gains plus prejudgment interest, a civil penalty, and a bar against him from appearing as an expert in any future criminal case.  On May 2, 2018, the Honorable Joseph G. Sansone of the U. S. District Court for the Northern District of California entered a temporary restraining order against Beers, ordering him to surrender his passport, and barring him from participating in the issuance, purchase, offer, or sale of any security deposit in the United State.  Separately, the SEC filed a civil injunctive action in federal district court in New York, charging Beers with violating Section 13(b)(5) and 14(e) of Exchange Act Rule 13b2-1, and charging him with aiding and abetting Beers’s violations of Rule 12b-20, and with violating Sections 206(1), 206(2), and 206(4) of Investment Advisers Act of 1940 and Rule 206(3)-8 thereunder. The SEC seeks permanent injunctions, civil penalties, and officer-and-director and penny stock bars against all defendants, as well as a conduct-based injunction against future violations of Section 17(a)(1) and (3) of The Securities Act of 1933 and Rule 17a-1 thereunder and Section 10b(b).
